<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetResourceName:
```c
int32 OS_GetResourceName(osal_id_t object_id, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    size_t              name_len;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* sanity check the passed-in buffer and size */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buffer_size);

    /*
     * Initially set the output string to empty.
     * This avoids undefined behavior in case the function fails
     * and the caller does not check the return code.
     */
    buffer[0] = 0;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id), object_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(&token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            name_len = OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size);
            if (buffer_size <= name_len)
            {
                /* indicates the name does not fit into supplied buffer */
                return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
                name_len    = buffer_size - 1;
            }
            memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len);
            buffer[name_len] = 0;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}

int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

OS_common_record_t *OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    uint32 base_idx = OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    return &OS_common_table[base_idx + token->obj_idx];
}

void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}

explanation:
Fragments not listed are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 or do not involve string.h functions that could access memory beyond the referenced objects. Specifically:
- The initial buffer[0] = 0 assignment is safe because OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer) ensures buffer is non-NULL and OS_CHECK_SIZE(buffer_size) guarantees buffer_size > 0.
- The final write buffer[name_len] = 0 is bounded: when a name is detected to not fit the supplied buffer the code sets name_len = buffer_size - 1, and buffer_size was validated, so this write does not exceed the buffer bounds.
- The object ID / token handling calls (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_ObjectIdRelease, and related token conversions) do not themselves call string.h functions and are not relevant to this string-bounds rule.
- The pointer/size validation macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_CHECK_SIZE) are not string.h operations and thus outside the scope of Rule 21.17.

The reported fragments include all uses of standard string.h routines (memchr via OS_strnlen and memcpy) or calls that pass pointers/lengths to them; these should be investigated to ensure the memory referenced by record->name_entry is at least as large as the length parameter supplied.
